content.description: A wide hands crack leads to a crux overhang finish.
content.location: This is the first crack system to the right of the Banana Cracks, and starts at the same height as they do.

climbs.name: Right Banana Crack
climbs.fa: Jon Lonne, Dave Ohlson, and Martin McBirney, April 1976

content.description: The Banana Cracks can be a good place to climb on a cold day, as the formation somewhat blocks out the wind.  The formation comes into the sun by late morning.  The Right Banana Crack was one of the hardest routes in the 1977 guidebook.  It is an exciting lieback and hand crack, with great protection.
content.location: The Banana Cracks are unmistakable.  They are about four feet apart at the start, and then diverge as the right one arches out under a roof.   Scramble up from the left to get to the large ledge at the base of the cracks.

content.description: Fun climbing punctuated with a very short tips lieback crux.
content.protection: Mostly thin to fingers. Take small to med stoppers and cams up to .75 camalot. Anchor takes stoppers, tips sized cams, and/or .5 camalot to #2 camalot.
content.location: Obvious thin crack/dihedral line 15' left of the Left Banana Crack, topping out on the shoulder of the formation. Approach from the left via 4th class gully, or the right via easy scrambling to a short hand traverse (from the right is much easier IMO). Descend by downclimbing climbers' left of the route.

climbs.name: Left Banana Crack
climbs.fa: Jon Lonne, Dave Ohlson, and Martin McBirney, April 1976

content.description: The Banana Cracks can be a good place to climb on a cold day, as the formation somewhat blocks out the wind. The Left Banana Crack is a fun, short, well protected finger and hand crack, with a mild overhang.
content.location: The Banana Cracks are unmistakable.  They are about four feet apart at the start, and then diverge as the right one arches out under a roof.   Scramble up from the left to get to the large ledge at the base of the cracks.

climbs.name: Banana Peel
climbs.fa: Peter Hayes, Dave Tidwell & Jeff Constine, November 1990

content.description: Steep, with the typical crimpy delicate face moves often found at J-tree. This route ascends the steep face right of the Banana cracks above the hand traverse. The obvious way to finish the route is to join the Right Banana crack where the crack gets larger and offwidthy.
content.location: On the steep face right of Right Banana Crack

content.description: This is the incredible arete to the right of "banana peel" it climbs thin face and overhang through 4 bolts up a picture perfect orange/white granite arete. Miramonte has this route listed as unknown. I would be very curious to hear more about this route and it's history as it is an great climb and beautiful.
content.location: The start is better approached from the right side of the banana cracks, near the wide crack. The climb is the right next bolted route of banana peel. You will only see 3 bolts from the start of banana peel the 1st bolt is down low on the rightside of the arete.

content.description:
An ok little warmup if you're here for something else on the Banana Crack formation.  Start on an off-vertical crack in a small dihedral leaning slightly right.  Traverse right once you get to a horizontal face crack and then follow the second crack system up and left to the top.  Scramble off the back.

For a much more exciting climb, try doing it in 24 degree weather.
content.protection: Plenty of opportunity up the whole route.  Standard rack to 3"
content.location: On the opposite face as the majority of the climbs on the formation; faces the road.
